entry.title: Pashinyan calls Assad and Erdogan, as Armenia sends rescue teams to disaster zone

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan calls Assad and Erdogan, as Armenia sends rescue teams to disaster zone
media:group.media:description:
üìçIn the aftermath of Monday‚Äôs devastating earthquake in Syria and Turkey, Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan held separate telephone conversations yesterday evening with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. Armenia has sent a 29-member rescue team to Syria and a 27-member team to Turkey, according to the Interior Ministry. üìçErdoƒüan thanked Pashinyan for his solidarity and noted that the Turkish government highly values Armenia‚Äôs support, especially in terms of deepening dialogue between the two countries, which do not have formal diplomatic relations. It was Pashinyan‚Äôs second phone call ever with Erdoƒüan.
Credits: Ruptly

entry.title: Armenia says it received more peace proposals from Azerbaijan

media:group.media:title: Armenia says it received more peace proposals from Azerbaijan
media:group.media:description:
French President Emmanuel Macron has once again called for the Lachin corridor, the only route between Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh to be reopened. German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock too called for the blockade to ‚Äúend immediately‚Äù during a press conference with her Armenian counterpart.

entry.title: Are the US and EU trying to oust Russia from the South Caucasus?

media:group.media:title: Are the US and EU trying to oust Russia from the South Caucasus?
media:group.media:description:
Paul Stronski, a senior fellow in Carnegie's Russia and Eurasia Program, spoke to CivilNet about the EU‚Äôs decision last month to deploy a two-year monitoring mission to the Armenian side of the border with Azerbaijan. Stronski also discussed the perception that the United States and European Union may be trying to oust Russia from the South Caucasus. He also touched on pushback within the EU against the mission to Armenia, and whether the U.S. and EU are working to deescalate the situation between Armenia and Azerbaijan and why.
